text:
Reviewed from saved notes.
The appearance was a semi-hazy yellow color with a super quickly dissipating fingers worth of white fizzy head. Quickly sliding lace.
The aroma had a huge vinous/white grape quality about it, spritzy lemon/citrus sharp qualities, and light mineral water.
The flavor was sour through the vinous/white grape quality and over doing the entire base. Aftertaste was the same and so was the finish.
The palate was light bodied with too much sour harshness distracting the overall enjoyment of this beer. Carbonation was also a bit too much. ABV did feel fine.
Overall, another overdone beer by Anchorage. Not a true witbier and also one that I wouldnt touch with a ten foot pole again.

Pours hazy light yellow with a medium frothy white head. Aromas of minerals, citrus, bananas, light honey, spices. Taste is fruity and citrusy with mineral notes. Mouthfeel is light bodied with moderate carbonation.

Pours hazy light yellow with low white head 
Aromas of orange peel, spices, oak, phenols 
Taste has notes of oak, spices, citrusy fruits, white wine barrel, phenols, hints of banana

[8787-20161015] 750mL bottle. Pepper toasted bread aroma. Slightly hazy, pale yellow body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Light peppery spiced straw flavour. Medium body. Average. (7/3/7/3/13) 3.3
(w/ jercraigs, mds)

750ml bottle pours out a hazy straw color topped with a white head. Nose is nice pepper lots of spice going on belg yeast some candy notes. Taste is more of the big pepper notes a blend of magic spices and a great finish.
Bottle from Liquor Barn into a pint glass. Aroma of coriander, hay, and basement aromas. I did not enjoy this at all.

Cloudy and hazy yellow with three finger head. Peppery aroma, wheat, lemon and spice. Lemon zest, peppercorns, a bit of heat and malted wheat/corn. Clean and balanced wit. Really really clean. So true to style that it almost comes across as dull. Its still great though.

Poured from a Batch 1, May 2011, 750 ml bottle. 
Aroma is light with some hints of wheat and light honey notes. Light citrus with faint pepper and coriander. Light pineapple and tropical fruit with hints of an earthy must. 
Pours a crystal clear, yellow straw color with a medium small, somewhat thin, white head that exhibits alright retention as it recedes to a thin film that lingers on the edges for a bit before disappearing. No lacing or legs. 
Flavor has a light sweetness with hints of wheat and honey. Light citrus notes with lemon and orange. Light coriander and hints of peppercorn. Some light tropical fruit and pineapple notes with hints of an earthy must. Some lingering honey notes and citrus. Medium low bitterness. Hints of chardonnay and oak. 
Mouthfeel is light bodied and a bit watery with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, Im not sure if its the age or not, but the beer is thin and the flavors and aromas are very muted. Its an ok beer, and clean, but it is lacking life.

Appearance: hazy pale straw with two fingers of rocky white head, good retention and moderate lacing. (4/5) Aroma: lemon zest, coriander, straw, white pepper. (8/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate funky tart, mild-moderate bitter. (9/10) Palate: medium-light body, lively carbonation, bone dry funky finish. (4/5)

Excellent - Brett funk dominates over a pale Witbier base. This is my kind of beer! I dont know how much I believe that 20 IBU, though: it feels a bit more bitter than that typically implies, possibly because of the astringency from the Brett. In fact, the flavours are more like a Saison or a Tripel, than a Witbier. Any way you slice it, though, this is a really good one. (17/20)

2016-10-15. Very lightly hazy yellow body, with a nice foamy white head. 3++ Aroma has a melange of spice notes. Pepper amongst other things. Reminds me of sausage somehow - not in a meaty way but the spicing. Flavour has similar spice, bit of grassy notes, light alcohol and muted fruit. Average bodied palate, good carbonation. Enjoyable. 7+/3-4/7/3/15 Bottle from Premier Gourmet, Buffalo."Theres some funny owl videos on YouTube."- mds

Based on style this is the prize winner for a wit. Poured into a tulip glass developing a big three fingered clean white head with hyperactive carbonation and soapy bubbles that Pop and fizzle yet remain pillowy in the glass. The appearance is a hazy yet vibrant sunshine golden yellow. The aroma is uniquely complex with the white pepper, lemon zest, coriander, straw, and a slight undertone of mellow buttery Chardonnay. In terms of taste this is a equally complex With yeast, wheat, lemon, coriander, pepper, and soft butter notes from the Chardonnay. Delicious and funky.

Bottle, shared at game night. Hazy pale yellow, huge white head that leaves thick sheets of lace. Aroma of pig manure and leather. Flavours of pineapple, leathery funk, and pepper. Bone dry. Fantastic.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: It pours pale yellow with a white head. It has various aromas with pepper, some funk (earthly) lemon, coriander, light wheat, and hints of citrus. It has flavors of lemon, spice, pepper, coriander, citrus with zest, low wheat, low earth, and hints of vinous quality. It has a medium-light body with a tart dry finish. There is a fairly high amount of carbonation. Overall, the additional of brett with the combination of other elements makes this one of the best witbiers that Ive tasted. The elements are in harmony with each other and it has the right touch of tart with the dry finish.

750ml corked bottle pours a hazy straw color with a generous white head that retains well and leaves some decent lacing on the glass. Aroma is lemon zest and coriander with some hints of oak and yeast. Taste is a spicy hop bitterness with a light lemon tartness and a fruity and malty sweetness. Medium bodied with abundant carbonation that tickles the tongue. Overall, a bold brew for the style, but balanced and tasty. Recommended.

Bomber shared by Paul. Anchorage whiteout brett witbier 6.5% 

A very light gold with a filmy wisp of white foam. A wheaty lemon and spice aroma with a light ultra dry body and wheat, brett, lemon and green hops but very minimal witbier character. More an American wheat than a belgian wit but good.

Pours a pale golden color. Super big white foamy head. Not much aroma. Slight citrus aroma. Taste is very light. Slightly hoppy slightly lemony. I cant get a handle on this. I guess it might be a nice Witbier. Not my thing
Aromaso more like a farmhouse. Super easy drinking. Slightly sweet finish. Refreshing. Balanced.

Bottle from a friend. Golden color, white head. Bitter taste with citrus, yeast, earthy notes, grass, a bit of oak and spices. Bitter finish with citrus, yeast, grass, oak, spices and grass. Excellent witbier.

750 ml corked and caged bottle. Aroma is funky brett, lemon, lotion, dusty basements, old books, floral, chalky candy. Pours extremely pale yellow with a thick soapy white head with great retention. Taste is dry with flavors of brett, lotion; I can taste black pepper, but dont think I would have noticed it without it being mentioned on the label. Likewise, I can pick out the chardonnay now that I know it was aged in barrels containing it, but Im not getting the oak itself. No coriander that I can tell, either. Its actually kind of bland. Well, it alternates between being interesting from the brett, to a watery blandness that Im not used to with well made examples of the style. Mouthfeel is champagne-level foamy. Its not bad, but its a bit of a letdown from the description on the label.

Bottle 75cl / Botella 75cl.
@ LaBIRRAtorium, Madrid, España.
A: Hazy golden / Dorado turbio.
T/S: Yeast, citrusy, slightly spicy / Levadura, citrico, ligeramente especiado.

Pours a hazy yellow golden color with fizzy white head. Citrus, coriander, funk, light tartness, and oak on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium bodied. Finishes with fruit, brett, and some light tartness.
ours a cloudy golden yellow with fizzy head. Aromas of citrus peel, yeast, hay, and some coriander. Flavors of coriander, a little vegatal, and some nice barrel. Tart beautiful wit.
Pours with a nice white foamy head. Belgian yeast aroma as expected. The Brett and oak flavors are not pronounced but are present. A tasty brew but not what I personally would call a standout.

Fra flaske på Mi2 Cardinal, jan-16: klar, svært lys strågul med flott skum som varer. Luftig, lett og elegant i uttrykket, både i aroma og smak. Sitrongress, pepper, dill, koriander er noen av ordene som går rundt i panelet. Kan humlen være Soraci Ace? Superelegant, reneste champagnen, stor begeistring hos alle. Superb palate. Ovesen ønsker seg bare et smørbrød med gravlaks til denne.

Shared bottle at Mi2 at Cardinal 18.01.16. Slightly cloudy pale yellow. Bright white head and lacing. Aroma of lemongrass and dill. Similar taste, with lemon and lime marmalade. Also some grass and chives. Complex and elegant. Lively carbonation. Dry. Very quaffable.

Shared bottle at Cardinal. Pours hazy straw with a small white head.. Inviting aroma, herbal and spicy with distinct dill. Lively and crisp mouthfeel. Taste is fresh and crisp, dry weak spicy, with champagne qualities, very drinkable.
Shared bottle @ Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours hazy light golden with white head. Aroma of bananas, ethanol, effervescent powder, white wine. Sweet and dry with a little sourness. High carbonation.
Bottle. Pours a clear yellow color with white head. Estery, brett, spicy, citrus aromas. Brett, spicy, write wine, wheat, slight citrus flavors. Really good beer!

750ml bottle - $15.00 at Tasty Beverage Company in Asheville, North Carolina.

Appearance: Pours a pale yellow body with noted clarity and a near nil, thin white head.

Smell: Harbors a scent of shredded crustless bread, old lemons-n-limes for a soft citrus nature and a fair amount of buttery white wine with a vein of mild, salty funk.

Taste: Very minor maltiness, only hinting a little hay-hewn cracked grains. Very minimal sweetness. A little lemon, a little lime and a sip of white wine giving a bit of buttery oakiness and subtly minerality. Slight albeit growing spiciness settles on the tongue, hinting at the peppercorns and earthy coriander. A bit more floral, citrus on the back-half. Drying, floral with a touch of orange juice on the finish.

Mouthfeel: Thin-bodied. Lightly carbonated.

Overall: An easy-drinking, albeit less than typical witbier. Though, for ones money, youd be just a well served by a Jolly Pumpkin Calabaza Blanca.

Bottle 750ml. Thx Tom10101.
Pours hazy blond with low white head. No lacing. Aroma is of bretts, rusticity, herbs, spices. Taste is of sourness, acidity, bretts. Palate: Light body. Very soft/low carbonation. Overall: Good. Sourness is not overdone.

Bottle (750 ml). Split 3-ways. Hazy yellow-golden with no head and no lacing. Aroma is weirdly very lambic-like with a pretty nice funk, some white winey and grapey notes, hints of vinegar and mild peppery presence. Taste definitely have something Belgian but no way I would be able to say its a "Wit" in a blind tasting. Acidity is moderate, again its quite lambic-like, the white wine is definitely noticeable but never overpowering, citrus notes and mild peppery presence. Medium body. Very soft carbonation, pretty close to being flat. Winey mouthfeel. Oaky. Dry and a bit puckering finish. Its tasty and flavorful but the lack of carbonation is certainly hindering drinkability and enjoyability. The bottle we had was much closer to unblended lambic than to a tradtionnal Wit. Tasty .

750 ml bottle, as Anchorage Whiteout Wit Bier With Brett, soon available at Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 6.5%, 20 IBU. Extremely pale yellow colour, moderately hazy. Moderate white head. Aroma of citrus / lemons, lemongrass, coriander, black pepper and dill. The flavour has the same elements as the aroma, medium dry, refreshing. Only a hint of brett and white wine.

The Sampler, Brooklyn bottle: pours hazy wellow with a white head. The brett is subtle in the aroma and in the taste, at least as compared to many other brett beers. Aroma is spices, coriander especially, light lemony citrus, and tree. Taste is lightly bitter with all them apicy notes. Some light pepper and low sweetness. Pretty good. Subtle. To the uninitiated, I am tempted to say they would be hard-pressed to see how different this actually is.

June 2015 bottle. Pour is light yellow with a medium white head. Aroma is lightly Funky and lightly bretty with some plastic notes and a touch of citrus. Flavor is spicy and bretty up front with some black pepper notes and light citrus. Nose and flavor pretty much match up. Clean. Long, dry, spicy finish.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a pale slightly hazy yellow with white head. Aroma is sour brett, lemon, coriander. Taste is moderate to heavily sour tart with flavors of citrus fruit, a little wine grape, grass, yeast. Pretty good for a sour wit. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour was a hazy unfiltered dark purple coloring, big tan head that retained. Smell of citrus, lemon peel, peppery and earthy, big yeasty smell. Taste follows: citrus is subdued but comes barking back at the finish. Big sour and bitter clash, a long bitter after taste. Dry, leathery finish.
(bottle) cloudy pale yellow colour with a small white head; fizzy carbonation; aroma of funk, sourness, then leather; balanced flavour with a long, medium bitter finish

appearance: cloudy bright gold, short fizzy white head, quickly vanishes to a soapy ring.  aroma:  some toasted white bread,	a bit of white wine, coriander, citrus, general funk. taste: taste is typical wit, undercut by an extensive, exhausting sharpness from the brett.  finish: lingering plasticky sharpness, nearly mineral. notes: 	Really, really wanted to like this. Felt like someone took a wit and just overwhelmed it with brett. Maybe my taste buds were just off, because everyone else seems to like it, and it sounded right up my alley.  Bottle from Sarah for Annibeersary 2015 via Craft Beer Kings.

Hazy straw yellow in color... Aroma of Chardonnay oak, wheat, coriander, lemon peel... Flavor is Chardonnay buttery oak, lemon peel, with Brett notes throughout... Solid beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, cloudy light yellow, almost no head. Aroma kombucha and cider, lightly funky. Taste is dry cider/kombucha, lemon, faint black pepper and oak. This is pretty sour. Palate is light, carbonation moderate.
Bottle 2014: Poured hazy yellow bubble head. Aroma is really funky eggs sulfur. Taste nice tart, chardonnay and wood with lemony zest.

(750ml bottle thanks to Adam C) cloudy medium gold yellow, no real head after pouring and settling. Nose of chardonnay, brett, tart, lemon, coriander, mild bugs, touch of oak, complex and delicious. Taste of lemon peel, brett, a little dry, chardonnay, oak, light sour bugs, an exceptional witbier. Medium carbonation, somewhat soda-like.
750 ml. shared bottle. Pours a somewhat cloudy pale gold with a small white head. Aroma of citrus, yeast, spice, and wood. Taste is lemon, orange, yeast, oak, and spice. Very good.

750 ml bottle poured into a Spiegelau tulip. Batch 3, June 2014. Clear straw yellow with about a finger of off-white head. Aromas of funk, citrus, herbs, some white wine, a bit of Brett. Tastes of citrus, funk, light wheat, white wine, light tart acidic notes, subtle herbs. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Nicely balanced and well done.

Hazy straw colour. No head. Aroma has brett, coriander, and sort of wheaty character. A slight tartness, but more crisp brett and fresh wheaty malt notes. The chard barrel lends a snappy quality to the finish.

Awesome white wine aromas that have tons of melon, lemon, and grassiness. Very pale straw color with little carbonation. Taste is delicious with ripe apples up front and the oak from the barrel smoothing things out. Very dry finish. Wish it had a tad more carbonation to make the flavor a pop a little more.

Bottle at home. Pours lightly hazy gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is fragrant earthy and barnyard yeast notes, Brettanomyces, light lemon notes, wheat malt and coriander with floral notes. Flavor is tart and acidic lemon, earthy and funky Brettanomyces, light hops and bitterness, wheat malt and a dry finish. Light body and medium carbonation.

Whiteout has one of the best names and one of the coolest bottles youll ever see. Review over. Just kidding. Whiteout is pale and heady, as youd expect. Aroma has citrus, spices, earthy Brett, and oaky Chardonnay notes. Flavor reveals savory spice, vinous fruit, lemon, orange peel, and of course, Brett. Despite all the complexity, Whiteout is soft and thirst-quenching. You definitely wont notice the increased ABV. While this isnt an orthodox Belgian White, its a damn good one.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2017 Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow color with white head. Yeast, spice, fruit, brett and white wine aroma. Yeast, lemon, brett, wheat, coriander, pepper and wheat flavors. Light body and average carbonation. Lemon and brett finish. Batch #3, #5.

Bottle.

A- Sour, tart, lemons, citrus, vinegar.

A- Pale yellow color, clear liquid, white head.

T- Sour, tart, sweet, citrus, vinegar.

P- Light body, average texture, average carbonation, sour finish.

O- Prior to this I had the Galaxy White IPA. After this I am now convinced I do not like Anchorage. White IPAs and Witbiers are two of my favorite styles. Throw in this Brett shit and charge me an outrageous price for the bottle and I am not pleased. To me, the Galaxy and Whiteout tasted the same. Two different styles and both tasted like the same thing. A not so good sour. Big let down.

750ml bottle from El Cerrito Liquor in Corona, California. Batch #3, June 2014. Clear light yellow in colour with a thin white head, light lacing. The aroma has some lemons, yeast, oak and spice. The flavour is of moderate citrus, fairly sweet, bretty, yeast, wheaty. Finishes with a light tartness, a little dry.

Batch #3 juillet 2014. Une robe jaune dorée pâle avec une mousse blanche. Un nez qui empeste le soufre et lacide citrique. La bouche est acide, jai dit acide, cest très acide, du citron. Il semble avoir une touche épicée. En finale cest aqueux, les saveurs se dissipent rapidement. Une balle tombante comme celle de Dennis Martinez.

Dès le versement, mon verre dégage des odeurs dufs pourris. Ce parfum indésirable ne sestompe pas entièrement En bouche, je note une facette épicée à ce liquide qui goûte un peu le fromage et, minimalement, le citron. Au palais, jai la sensation dun corps sans véritable colonne vertébrale. En finale, tout se passe très vite : cest peut être une bonne chose après y avoir bien pensé. Batch #3. Juillet 2014.
Pours pale yellow and hazy. Thin white head. Lots of citrus and spice on the nose. Palate is the same with the noticeable brett. Short finish and thin body. Easy drinking.

750ml bottle pours a golden color without any head. Been cellaring this one for about 9 months and it's lost a lot of its carbonation. Seems better to drink fresher. Great Bret flavors coming through.
light fresh and light citrus aroma,pale, clear, white foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, fresh light citrus finish.

750ml bottle, slight cloudy blonde hue, with a ring of white head, with a mild musty white berry, faint cheesy, wild funky bretty yeast nose, with some zesty lemon peel, faint spicy coriander, tart green apple, bread dough accents, and a faint white wine tannin, wet oak barrel, subtle wheat malt sour mash note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a mild funky, bretty, wild yeast, zesty fruity lemon peel, faint lemon juice, subtle wheat malt sour mash acidic character, with a lemon pie, faint spicy coriander, lemongrass, subtle black peppercorn, wet oak barrel, white wine tannin, bread dough flavour, leading towards a lemon juiciness, fruity tartness, lingering yeast funkiness, white wine dry tannin finish.
Nice Head, good brett and great funky aroma. Taste makes it hard to put down. I am salivating just writing this review.
Bottle at craft ale house. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. The aroma has a nice tart lemon and light peppery notes. The taste is light sour Lemon, semi tart finish. Nice.

Bottle. Peppery lemon and sour aroma. Hazy yellow body with thin lasting head, nice lacing. Flavor begins sour with strong lemon notes, followed by brett yeast and hints of peppery spice and chardonnay. An awesome sour wit

Flaska från Demolen. Smak och doft av vita druvor, jäst, äpple, fat, vete, trä, citrus, koriander med toner av örter och apelsin. Känsla av vitt vin. Frisk och syrlig, lagom sötma, en aning kryddig i efterbeskan. Väldigt gott!

Flaska från Demolen. Gyllengul, lätt disig med ett högt vitt skum, liknar champagne. Doft av vita druvor, jäst, fat, vetesyra, citrus, koriander. Frisk, krispig, kryddig med en lite fet munkänsla. Fina chardonnay-smaker som ger djup och extra dimension till smaken, fat, kryddor, peppar, vete, jäst. Frisk, gott och flerdimensionellt komplext och riktigt gott.
Light yellow coloured and clear. Has a white head, diminishing. Fruity, yeasty aroma, nice skunk. Sweet flavor, moderate bitter finish.
Bottle. Frothy White good mostly lasting head. Greenish yellow colour. Light bitter flavor. Citrus notes. Average light bitter finish. Oily palate.

750mL bottle, June 2014. Awesome aroma - Brett, tartness, vinous, citrus, fruity, lots of awesome. Nice orange pour with a good off-white head, nice lacing. Okay flavor, disappointing given the aroma I was digging. A bit sweeter, more orange and spice, less tart presence than I was expecting, doughy. Not bad.
это пиво очень вкусно. я бы, конечно, рекомен& его всем. пожалуй& обратит& его. очень хорошо!

Bottle:
Clear, bubbly, sparkling. tan-gold with a small white head..
Light, lemon-apple, peppery scent.
Taste is tart, bret, light fruit, wheat...
Lemony.
Nicely tart.
Bottle. Barnyard, pepper, coriander, and lemon malt aroma. Hazy pale yellow with moderate head. Sweet tart lemon malt, white wine, and brett flavor. Okay - brett dominates.

750 mL bottle. Pours a pale yellow-gold, smallish to nonexistent head but quite carbonated (looks more like champagne than beer). Nose is funk dominated, some mineral notes, grass, musty barrel, sulfur, lemons. Mouth is dry and funky, bretty, mildly bitter, tart, green apples, key limes, hay, chardonnay, oak, white pepper. The Brett makes this more like a sour than  a Wit. I also drank this really cold, so not sure what was lost due to the temp, but I quite enjoyed it all the same. I wish Anchorage beers werent so erratic so far as distribution goes... one of my favorite brewers, but a rarity to find on Binnys shelves.

Excellent delicate beer. Straw colored with big white head and excellent retention. Brett, citrus, funk, lemongrass in the aroma. Taste had more of a yeasty-peppery saison body than a wit beer. The brett was huge all over it. Lemon and oak were abound as well. Nice light body. Really enjoyed this one.

Bottle sample at a sour tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks Noam. Pours pale yellow with a small head, aroma of brett, wine, grape juice, flavor of brett, wine, grape juice, brett, wood, medium bodied.
not really sure id call it a wit, at least flavor-wise. really was more like a saison.
UPDATED: SEP 29, 2015 Scarcely resembles a witbier, more like a tart American saison with some light spiciness, a bit of bretty funk, lively carbonation, and the aforementioned light tartness.

Very pale blonde pour with a soft haze and two fingers of crackling white head. Nose is very nice funky and earthy upfront with a nice acidity and yeasty quality. Light acidity in the flavor that presents itself as a pleasant tartness at the front of the mouth. Yeasty with an earthy malt character and rustic note. Light and dry with a very soft carbonation and tart finish.
Bottle in Florida. Wheat, floral aroma. Witbier flavor & pour but bit too much lemon. Mediocrity at its finest for the genre.

Bottle from the Syb Pig in Boca. Pours a nice hazy straw color with a thick head. Aroma is citrus with lemon and orange zest, brett, slight oak barrel, and some pepper spices. The taste is front end very citrus and then the brett and pepper come on the end. I had a tough time finding the coriander, but that was fine. Heavily carbed, clean, refreshing, somewhat tart finish for the style. Very good.

Yellow with a small pale head. Aroma is brett funk, orange peel, peach, hint of oak. Light bodied, tart on the palate with a fruity sweet finish. Taste is orange blossom, lemon peel, brett funk, coriander.

Clear pale golden colour, white head. Aroma of pineapple, quite spicy, 5 spice, chipolata, winegums. Quite herbal flavour, wheat, malts, fruity, light bitter, hint of soap. Herbal finish, wheat, peel, spicy, citrus, apricot and winegum. Interesting brew.(from 66cL bottle @ Joris & Judys Dinner Party. Thanks for sharing, joes!)

Bottle sample at a sour tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks Noam. Batch #2, 3/12. Pale yellow with a white head. Aroma of wood, brett, white wine, fruits and a bit of spiciness. Sourish flavor, vinous, woody, with fruits (quite citric), brett, some spiciness and some bitterness. Medium-bodied, lively carbonation.

A hazed light, sunny yellow body sits beneath a fading half inch frothy-tight white head falling to a solid ring with a few dots of lace

Initially, the adjuncts merge with the yeast and barrel to create a dominate stanky-cheesy funk note, which at times gives way to cleaner, brighter notes of lemon peel, spices, bright earthy barn, and chardonnay with smooth transitions on a creamy, mildly carbonated medium-light body offering a clean, vinous, lemony-tart residual

750ml cork and cage Batch #3 2014 served at 45º and warming into Orrefors Beer Taster

750ml from Johns Grocery. Real nice bier clerk sent me this one. Excellent service. Pours a pale yellow color with a minimal head. Aromas of lemon and citrus, with some oak and funk tossed in for good measure. Taste is semi sweet and lightly bitter, even for the style. Flavors of straw, lemon peel, light oak. Finish is slightly sweet and sweaty. Pretty solid.

"a standout in the style, if only because it no longer really fits the style. the wit base makes itself known only in color and feel. the smell is mostly wild diaper, and the flavor brett and oak, with very light chardonnay aspects. good beer, but too steep in price. ill be curious about future releases from this new brewery, though. brewer spent 13 years at midnight sun..."

Light 10 karat pour with ample carbonation and a tightly packed ivory cap. Lemongrass, hay, some funk, white wine, coriander, crushed black pepper, and biscuit. Lots going on here, but it all seems to meld together nicely. Yum!

Hazy yellow body with a small white head. Complex aroma of coriander, wheat, light misc. spice, grass, floral notes, white wine. A tasty beer for sure. Additional notes of tart citrus and black peppercorns. Saison characteristics. Delicious.
Bottle. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a nice white head. Aroma of lemon, brett, fruit, oak and citrus. Flavor was sweet and fruity with lemon peel, white wine, yeast, brett, oak and pepper.

Pale yellow colour, white head. Aroma of white wine, wet wood, dough, citrus, basement aromas. Taste is quite complex, slight sweet, slight sour, a bit bitter. Light body, slick texture, average carbonation. Very interesting , I like it a lot.

March 2012 bottle. Pours clear gold carb that fades quickly. Aroma has an almost cloying quality that is not immediately identifiable to me, possible the brett or a combo of the brett and Chardonnay? Its almost like coconut. Taste is less unusual with lemon, pepper, oak. Lightly tart. Pretty good.

Bottle thanks to Rick. Pours a cloudy yellow with a frothy white head that lasts. The aroma is belgian yeast, oak, and clove. Thin mouthfeel with nice citrus, clove, brett and nice dryness, very good.
Bottle - Vintage 2011 - Lemon, Brett and bit of wheat. Pale yellow with almost no head. Light lemon and Brett with almost nothing else.

Bottle shared at the daje reaches 2000 ratings sessions
Yellow hazy, white head. Smells of white wine, orange zests, spices and funk, some fruity esters in there. Moderate sweet, quite fruity, nice funky brett, some wine acids, pepper, some orange zests as well. Moderate bitter finish. Very nice take on the wit style. Anchorage sure makes thing their own way

Bottle. Pours hazy pale yellow with a white head. Aroma of funk, grapes, oak, citrus and some peppery notes. Falvor is sweet and fruity with some pepper, oak, white wine, funk, coriander and peppercorns. Medium to thin body, lively carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2016 Bottle at Cafe Sara, may 7th 2014. Hazy golden body with a lively white head. Aroma of flowers, citrus fruits, barnyard, clove and brett. Taste is acidic with a bretty lemon and grapefruit taste, grapes, spicy yeast. Quite fresh and nice! Funky and bitter aftertaste of fruit zest, grapes and peppercorns. An incredibly nice beer!
Big bottle at home. Pale clear golden beer with auge offwhite lacy head. Spicy, hay, woody, grassy sourish aroma. Hoppy, floral spicy flavour with erathy and lemongrass notes.

poured from a bottle. smell of grapes. light color, white foamy head. Very sour, reminds me of a champagne more than a beer. Aroma of lemon, pepper, some vanilla. very carbonated. Overall a decent beer, but would not drink again for the price.
Pours a lovely straw gold with a white head. Has a subtle. Has a slight lemony taste that goes down smooth.
Hazed yellow. White head. Wit beer meets barrel meets saison. Cool! Spice, pepper, white wine, light grapey notes, yeast.

750ml bottle. Hazy pale gold shade with a large white fluffy head. Aroma: lemony, brett funk, white grape, white wine in general. Taste is honey, grape, apple, lemon, perfume. Lovely balance. Witbiers have never done it for me but anything Anchorage touches seems to turn to gold.
Sour smell of apple. Lemon colour, white foamy head. Very sour. Aroma of lemon, pepper, some vanilla. Cantillon gueuze style flavour. Rich in carbon. When warmer, also coriander to be found.
Bottle @ home. Aroma is bretty fruity woody white. Flavour is light tangy red fruity, light hoppy etc etc. Lrab

Considering the hype I was a little underwhelmed. Pours almost like a white wine with flimsy, soapy head. Aroma is dominated by peppercorns and coriander and that acidic sour quality of brett. Beautifully crisp and quite dry, bouncy palate like a sparkling white wine. Taste is lemon peel some sour farmy notes and again peppercorns. Theres an enigmatic sorachi-ace quality in mid-palate - some ginger and a little cardboard. Finish leaves a minty medicinal hue which is not to my taste.

Bottle shared by judyvv @ Van Moll Brewpub. Hazy pale yellow color, small foamy white head that diminishes very quick. Very nice aroma of fruits, lemon, lemonpeel, lightly brett. Taste is lovely: again very fruity, lightly brett, lemonpeel. Superb balance, smooth and suitable body, tickling carbonation. Oh this is a lovely beer indeed! Very nice!
Pours an yellow slightly unclear beer with a good white head. Smells sour, fruity. Tastes fruity, sour. Cant say much about it. Fizzy carbo, thin body and a dry texture.

A: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, Mild Head Ring, No Lacing

Overall, for a brett beer, this one was just way under carbonated and watery.

Bottle. Pours cloudy golden with a frothy white head. Aroma is fruity, grapes, yeast, a tad funky, some red fruits and malts. Flavour is moderate sweet and light bitter. Very pleasant mouthfeel, thin but not too thin. Medium body with average carbonation. Another great beer from Anchorage.

Relativ klar im aussehen, leichte säure im aroma, angenehme rezenz, würzig, pfeffer im abgang nachklang angenehm spürbar.

From 9/22 notes. Pours hazy light pale yellow gold into tulip. Nose is oak, funk, grapes, hint of tartness. Mouthfeel is bright, crisp and carbonated. Taste is woody, big barrel notes, grains, hay, citrus, lemon, buttery, oak, funk, white wine, grape, cheese. Finish is biscuity, nilla wafers, oak barrels. pours brilliant gold with a large white head that quickly fades away. Aroma is a nice blend of sweet malt & brett funk.
Flavor is really brett forward. Very tart & funky with almost no malt character with a crisp clean finish. Nice!

Bottle from Pivoteka Beergeek, Prague. Cloudy pale yellow color with medium white head. lambic tartness, wheat, spices, earthy notes in aroma. Taste. wheat, lemon, earthy brett, notes, grapes, light bitterness, coriander. Sour bitter finish. Lovely beer.

750 ml bottle from beersofeurope.co.uk. Golden cloudy with a smaller head than some wits. This smells strongly sweet, fruity and delicious and the taste has some tart citrus to balance the sweetness, though the finish is short and a tad watery. Above average wit but not quite Premier League.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2015 My Bottom Line:
Lacto funk acidity, elderberry juice and lemon verbena allusions are topped with peppercorns in this dry and elegant wheat beer interpretation.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sliver of foam surrounds the hazy yellow shine.
-The first sips are quite Berliner Weisse-like.
-The aroma is a combination of crushed peppercorns, lactobacillus and lemon peel.
-The spicing dosage is intelligent, like it always is for an Anchorage brew.
-Yet another compelling brew from Anchorage. This guy can do no wrong, it seems.

Bottles.

Clear yellow pour, lasting carbonation and a nice slight funky sweet aroma. Flavor is effervescent white grapes, pears and a little dry on the aftertaste. Has a lot of "wine" qualities . Good but not may favorite of this style.

Batch #2, March 2012.
Appearance: The body is clear with lots of carbonation present in the pale golden body. The head is short with mediocre retention, settling into a thin white coating.
Aroma: The aroma leans dry and tart with lemons, leather and straw being prominent with sweet orange and an earthy presence taking a back seat.
Taste: The intro is of slightly tart lemon backed by crisp wheat. The mid presents slight tannins with dry leather. This leads to a bit of a seltzer water finish that is rather abrupt.
Palate: Light bodied with high carbonation.
Overall: This is a great beer, but its lost its brightness I experienced as short as 6 months ago. This is batch is over the hill, but its still a good beer. I wouldnt pay $15 again for this batch or anything older though.

Bottle at Cotteridge Wines during the RB Black Country bash. Thanks for putting this on. I must have had about 4 tasting cups of this. Golden yellow with a persistent white head. Fruity brett horse aroma. Orval smashed up with a west coast ipa. REally good stuff.

Two tasting cups while on the RB Black Country Bus trip: sorry if I took someone elses cup, but one wasnt enough to rate/review properly for me.

Pale, but bright urine colour with a froth of white bubbles.

Aroma was semi-sour white wine and musty yeast, throw in some lemon peel for good measure.

The taste a mixture of the smells with added spice notes along with a grainy hint.

Fine beer: sadly my taste buds were not too sharp by the time this arrived, in fact they might even have been a bit shoddy!

Hope Ive done the brew justice.

750ml bottle. Pours a hazy light gold, with a minimal white head, which fades rapidly and leaves no lacing. Brettanomyces sourness mixes with oaky chardonnay, lemon zest and coriander to create an unusual but appealing aroma. It is quite sour up front, with some apple skin notes and a hint of spice. Smooth oaked chardonnay leads into witbier spice and black pepper in the body. The finish is more typically witbier, with the lemon, coriander and pepper showing through, but there is a little sourness to shake things up. This is a long way from being a standard witbier; the brettanomyces and chardonnay barrels have made it a very different, but highly enjoyable wit.

Bottle at Cotteridge Wines during the RB Black Country bash - thanks guys and thanks to Bish and Dom for being the waitressees, 06/07/13.
Lightly hazed pale blonde with a good sized white head.
Nose carries soured fruit notes, tarte lemon, bitter orange, sugars.
Taste comprises light brett notes, tarte orange, soured lemon, yeasty notes, grape skins.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, tangy fruit finale.
Very good drop !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Sampled at Cotteridge Wines, during RB Black Country Crawl. Pretty good I reckon. Rather dry. Not the biggest of flavours, but palatable.
Shared 660ml bottle. Pours pale lemon with a small head. Aroma is Brett, cats piss and coriander. Taste has cats piss to start and coriander and Brett in the finish. Really enjoyed this.
Poured beautifully. Just takes a bit of time to get back used to this shit. I think its the third fermentation that really takes this beer to the next level.
Bottle at Cotteridge Wines; straw yellow pour with lively white head, tart wine like aroma, tart metallic Brett action some floral taste.
Hmmmm, not really my thing but other people raved about it. Maybe I need to revisit.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2013 650 ml bottle. Batch #1. May/2011. From bierkompass.de.

Lambic-like sourness, tartness, mild sweetness and some spices in the aroma. The flavour is much sweeter. Theres mild butter, toffee, sourness, mild bitterness, horse radish and some citrus. Very tasty. Delicious.
Pale yellow body , white head. Aroma has lots of vinegar and wheat. Nice wheaty grains and nice brett in semi malty acidic environment. Lots of relish in flavour.
Best wit ive had to date! I love the lemon and Brett combo. Very complex. Delicious
Batch #1 May 2011. Pours a hazed light golden color with a finger of white fizz. Lots of dusty dry horse-blanket notes mingle with lemon zest, vinous oak and a dry bittering spice on the finish.

Had in PDX, probably at Belmont Station, a few years back.  Peachy soured mash nose, hints of spice.  Citrus malt up front, fruited middle, with a nice sour brett kick towards the end thats blended quite well.  This brewery is amazing.  Really.

Hazy yellow with a thin white head. Bright lemony aroma. Sharp start but finishes dry with hints of wheat and citrus

Bottle.  Pours super light yellow and fizzy, almost champagne-looking.  This drinks with a definitive funky edge, a certain wild aspect that carries like some old, water-logged wood. Im not as high on this as others ... dont care for the over-effervesence in combination with the overly complex combination of flavor components.  (#5026, 5/22/2013)
750ml bottle pours a straw yellow with foamy white head. lemon zest aroma. Tart lemon and wood taste.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2016 Bottle @home. Light yellow hazy. Small head. Spicy citrus Brett pearch ananas aromas. Tartness rules; vanilla nutty flavours. Complex and great. Retasted 21/3-16. Easter week. Guren alone. Big white well lasting foam. Floral dry coriander. Bitter finish low Brett low sourness. Great brew. Complex and very drinkable.

75cl bottle split wth Tomaz @ home.
Dorée claire devenant trouble mi-bouteille, col fin blanc champenois.
Arôme est boisé avec un petit côté vin blanc, raisin le tout accompagné dun bouquet épicé agréable. Le brett rajoute aux effluves boisées et fruitées qui restent correctes pour le style de la bière.
Palais est ici aussi légèrement boisé avec une petite note abricot, vin blanc, qcq agrumes sur ce Chardonnay léger et une pointe de coriandre. Le brett reste modéré, note de pelure agrumes pour une bière restant légère et complexe. Petite note de grains et malts avec un boisé épicé de chêne arrivant en toute fin de  bouche. Très bonne, à partager mais un poil chère.
Big thanks to JR for breaking this one out. Nice lemon zest in this one. Has a slight woody quality from the chardonnay barrels but nothing over the top. Slightly tart and maybe even a tad sour.
Poured from a 750ml bottle. Great packaging. Big citrusy, lemon, acidity in the aroma, malty, effervescent, doughy, dusty. A great wit beer.

Bottle from Market of Choice, Eugene. Pours a light cloudy golden color, little to no head. Aroma is heavenly; brett, funk, barrels, white wine, white fruit, sumptuous! Body is very lively, spice in coriander and pepper hits surprisingly strong in finish. Tart, bubbly, not as dry as one might think. Perhaps the most unconventional "wit" Ive had. Not bad, just VERY different...

75 cl corked bottle @ home. Pours cloudy pale yellow with a white head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma is citrus, spices, a little funk, oak, yeast, and white wine. Flavour is citrus, spices, funk, and white wine  with a dry finish.

Thanks to blutt59 for sharing this bottle. Light yellow color with a large white head. Aroma is heavy on the wheat and lemons with some light brett. Flavor is brett, leather, orange and wheat. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

From bottle at HOTB. Smooth yeasty Brett notes, sweet. Subtle nose by very nice. Cloudy straw-white with thin white head. Medium body with light carbonation. Starts yeasty and Bretty with sweetness and a hint of light funk or tartness. Tasty and smooth.

Bottled. Pours hazy, pale yellow with a mediumsized white head, that leaves a fair lacing. Aroma og lemon peel. citrus fruits, Wood, corriander, yeast and brett. Slightly sweet flavor that ens up dry and with bitter notes. Light to medium bodied, oily texture and average CO2. A nice and quite different wit. ★★★
Pale straw, hazy, off-white head.  Citric acidity, lemons, dry crackerlike malt, biscuit and wheat, light earthy funk, a little horse-blanket, grainy finish with effervescent carbonation.

Bottle @ Home. Pours hazy pale yellow with a fading white head. Aroma of yeast, little wheat, brett, oak, sweet tropical fruits, pineapple. Flavor is wheat, yeast, light brett, spice, pineapple, sweet tropical fruit. Thin body, lively carbonation, dry bitter finish. 060313

Hazy pale straw color; Light to medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of yeast, wheat, floral/fruit, citrus, & vinous notes; Flavor of wheat, yeast, citrus (notably lemon), some coriander, and spice; Finish is slightly tart/sour; Nicely balanced; Good - but I was expecting a bit more.

Corked bottle from A Tutta Birra, MilanThe cork opens with a loud pop; it pours a clear yellow color with generous frothy head, and some sparse perlage. Very nice aroma; there is some lemon, some vanilla, light biscuits, delicate Bretts; intriguing.There is too much carbonation, and the mouthfeel is totally dry, with poor flavor components, too much bitterness, and an after flavor of plastic.Not nice; and overly expensive.

750ml bottle shared by Olivier.
Appearance : Crystal clear pale yellow with medium creamy and fluffy white head. Long lasting head, lots of lacing.

Aroma : Amazingly aromatic. Delightful funk with a nice farmhouse character. Light citrusy and herbal notes. Lots of personality. Some wheat.

Taste : Horsey and funky. Herbal notes, nice clean and sharp finish. Citrusy notes. Some wheat.

Palate : Great fizzy carbonation, fluffy palate. 

Overall : Awesome beer. The funky witbier idea works really well for me. Very complex layers of farmhouse and funky notes. Very elegant and quite drinkable. Refreshing. Awesome beer.
Bottle (bomber) from bierkompass.de. Hazy golden, medium white head. Fruity aroma with notes of peaches and apricots. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Semi dry with medium bitterness.
Bottle. Pale golden colour with awhite head. Aroma is sourness, brett, citrus, wood, spices. Flavour is sourness, brett, citrus, wood, spices. Very nice beer.

Bottle: Poured a clear bright yellow color ale with a medium pure white foamy head with good retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of Brett and Chardonnay is quite dominant with light peppercorn and spicy yeast notes also perceptible. Taste is a good mix between some dry Brett notes with some Chardonnay notes with some clearly vinous notes and some spicy peppercorn notes which dont really fit in too well with the rest of the flavours. Body is light with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. This is quite enjoyable though with the amount of Brett and Chardonnay notes I am not sure I would call this a wit beer any more. Some spicy notes of peppercorn could be removed since they dont really bring anything valuable to the whole mix.

750 ml bottle. A clear and sparkling pale yellow beer, with a large, fizzy, mostly diminishing, white head. The aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers, grass), moderately yeasty (barnyard, cheese, dough, wet earth), with notes of lemon, clove, apple, some white wine and wood. The flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery texture, fizzy carbonation, really dry, medium length finish with almost moderate bitterness, lightly alcoholic. If I think at this beer as a Wit (a style Im not particularly into), its nearly excellent, but as an Anchorage Brewing beer its my least favorite product by them. Still several merits, from the nice funkiness to the integrated barrel and the drinkability.

Best wit ive had yet. Aroma full of citrus, lemon, grapefruit and a hint of strawberry. Taste of the same but without the strawberry and with a strong feeling of white wine. The foam lasts long enough and the color is yellowish white and non-transparent. One cant really handle all the different tastes and aromas that he gets at the same time by this masterpiece beer.

Bottle. Light hazy pale yellow with a bubbly white head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is fruity with raspberry, light pear, soapy citrus, light leather and wood, light coriander, wheat. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Medium body, oily texture, lively carbonation. Very refreshing and easy to drink.
This is crazy good, really. Batch #1, May 2011. This is like drinking a 3F geuze without the acidity. Loads of funk, loads. Fruity and basement. Outstanding, simple.

Bottle. Pours yellow with a fidy white head. Notes of brett, flowers and apricots in the aroma. Taste is crisp and citrusy. The brett adds some bitterness. A bit thin. Perfectly drinkable but - as with all the Anchorage offerings - its hand to sense the original beer style behind all the added attitude.

Bottle.
Pours hazy golden with a light bubbly head.
A nice tart and vinous brew, similar to their other brews but lighter.
From a bottle, pours a clear pale yellow and a foamy white head.  Bready, malty, yeasty, Brett and a little white wine aroma, taste is similar with some funk and minor lemon zest.  Good Stuff.

Bottle (May 2011, batch 1). Pours a very, very light, pale straw. Aroma of Brett, rotting grapes, lactic, citrusy hops and lemons. Wow, riot of flavor: light tartness, leather, earthy spiciness from the coriander, and old paper. All the taste is muted from the age. Very light body, with an odd tart, bitter finish.

750 ml bottle. Almost clear, pale yellow with a foamy white head. Aroma has a delicious mix of funky Brett and oak with a vinous touch. Flavor is sweet and slightly acidic, funky and oak. Not strong in flavor but fantastic delicate and complex. Medium body and a funky aftertaste with oak and pleasant acidity. Refreshing, easy to drink, complex and quite original as well.

A very complex beer. Do yourself s favor and be sure this one is at least 45 degrees or more warm - any under and the flavors separate. That said, very interesting beer - crisp, earthy, and oaky make for a wild combo.

from Erzbierschof - quite clear pale golden beer with a little long lasting white foam; perfumy with notes of hay and spices; subtle carbonation and medium-bodied; pretty tasty and gently acidic; quite dry and slightly salty; more acidic notes in an aftertaste of hay, spices and citrus - charming

Pours a quite bubbly chalky white-golden with light white head.  Aroma is funky-musty like wine and damp old wood and lemon peel.  Dry with nice tropical fruitiness and a hint of musty wine and brett.  It is very light yet complex and flavorful, very enjoyable.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2013 I dont normally like wit beers due to their overly sweet and cloying taste but this is just something else. Superb. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, 75cl corked, from trade with Papsoe. Its a pale one, yellowish golden, and topped by a small, dense, white head. Tasteful as hell, with lemon, funk, wood, generic fruityness, spice hints and some white sugar. Lasting finish. A really pleasant one. Dangerously easy drinkable. 121219

Crystal-clear, uttely pale yellow beer, heavily carbonated to white to transparant small head. Brett-like, vinous smells jumping upon pouring, lemon, sage, spicy; light, but very inviting nose with obvious white wine. Very nice, lemony acidity, vinous, and indeed Chardonnay (once read the caption, its unmistakable). Light, titillating-spritzy feel, refreshing. Surprisingly vious, Brett-like character. If Belgian witbiers really were like this, Id be a huge fan. Neeryssche Dobbele Witte, anyone?

Bottle. Pours hazy pale yellow, small white head, great lacing. Aroma is Brett, tart lemon, wheat. Flavor is the same, light sweet, light to medium tart, tangy finish. Light body, prickly carbonation. I am loving Anchorage beers!

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, Batch 2 bottled March 2012.  Pours lightly hazy golden straw color with a foamy 3 finger bright white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Spotty foamy lacing on the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation.  Aromas of tart apple, pear, lemon, white wine, hay, grass, funk, acidity, pepper, and yeast spiciness.  Fantastic aromas with huge complexity and balance.  Taste of apple, pear, lemon zest, white wine, pepper, floral, hay, grass, light funk, wheat, earth, and herbal spiciness.  Slight tartness and moderate earthy spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of lemon, pear, apple, white wine, pepper, hay, grass, wheat, earth, and herbal spiciness on the finish for a good bit.  Great flavor complexity and balance; with a nice malt/peppery flavor balance with nice brett flavors; and zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a very crisp, smooth, and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a highly excellent Wibier!  Huge complexity and balance of flavors; and extremely smooth to drink, though I prefer to sip on this one.  A highly enjoyable offering.

Courtesy of 5000 via trade

The flavor has light-moderate lemon/lemon grass, light floral notes, spice, and a touch of vinous notes.  Its light-medium bodied with mild carbonation.

750, corked and baled with a pretty silkscreen label. May of 11 batche one, opened nov of 12. Thanks j and a! Pours a clear pale gold with tons of nucleations and a rich fizzy white head. Picked this one up after really enjoying the galaxy IPA and bitter monk. This was bright yellow, a little cloudy. Smell was yeasty with just a hint of wine barrel, not bad. Id buy bitter monk again if I see it and Id love to try the lovebuzz saison but I would not buy this one again, especially for $15.

Bottle shared by Turd. Pours hazy bright light orange. Zesty nose and taste. Bright and lively and more tart/citric than usual from the style. Some butter/wood notes. Great.

Still, by the second glass, I was tired of it.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2012 Bottle at Ryans shared with friends. Pour is hazy straw in appearance with a big white head that quickly dissipated. Funk, dust, pineapple, spice, biscuit, yeast, and brett in the aroma. Crisp, dry, and funky, but super easy to throw back. I could drink this all day.

Body is light, with a slight fizziness.  Finishes light, but with a lingering mild dryness.  Bready yeast flavor gives way to a pleasant burst of lemon that has a note of rind to it.

Bottle shared with Bernat, thanks. Pours clourdy pale amber with a big white head. Aroma is like a lambic, very funky and quite sharp with some lemon and a slight pepperiness. Taste is similar, sharp and funky. Slightly sour and quite refreshing. This was delicios

750ml bottle from Wilburs in Fort Collins.  pours a hazy light yellow with a nice white head.  spice, lemon (Sorachi Hops), and light barnyard funk across the nose.  med body with layers of tart lemons, smooth oak, light Brett funk and bright citrus bitterness.  finishes crisp and tart with spices and citrus with an underlying barnyard presence.

Another terrific beer from Anchorage, damn. Thanks to Sam for sharing. A style that I generally an unmoved by, but these guys found quite the way of livening it up. Gorgeous appearance, as is typical of these guys. Slight tartness mingles with the bright fruit in the nose. Taste is nice, with some pineapple, butter from chard, and slight bitterness.

Batch 2: Pale yellow. Foamy, big-bubbled head noisily crackles as it mostly diminishes. One-dimensional nose is chock full of tropical-fruit wine-barrel extractives (nectarine, coconut, lemongrass, spicy oak), bretty pineapple, lactic acid, and white pepper phenolics. Vague "mousy" character coincides with some sulfur and straw, as well. Flimsy, seltzery carbonation. Rounded brett-derived twang is lightened by coconut-laden oak and prolific tropical fruit succulence. Poignant lemongrass and zesty tannin oak sharpness curb some of the slicker, more buttery chamomile notes which, along with a raw woodiness, stifles much of the potential luster. Fleeting crackery, toasted wood malt is dry and ghostlike, but fairly fuzzy and poorly defined. Very hollow at the core. Predominantly flowery hops merge with the ongoing softness which is prolonged by honeydew melon. Finishes with a glimpse of white pepper sass though predominantly buttery and obscurely marked with oak and nectarine. A deceptively ordinary beer with bells and whistles. The oak and brett unfortunately do little to enhance the witbier profile, which, IMO, has its inherent limitations to begin with. Vigorous swirls toward the end of the glass reveal a sterile and characterless base beer beneath the myriad tropical fruitiness, thus it comes off as a one-trick pony.

This one really threw me for a loop.  It says Belgian wit on the label but smelled like a sour.  Then the palate did not jerk me back the way I was expecting.  Finally, the taste was light, sweet, and not at all what I expect.  A very weird oddity for shizzle.

A steady pour into my small St. Sebastiaan tulip produces a fat-one-finger thick, pale, just off-white colored head. The beer is a pale gold color that shows a brilliantly clear, super pale gold hue when held up to the light. The aroma has a nutty woodiness to it, a pine like character somehow, or perhaps it is just a huge herbal note, sweet fruit aromatics of golden raisins and ripe melons, a peppery woody spice character, as well as a solid fresh cut wood / oak note. Earthy spice notes of coriander are here as well, but this is a subtle base note that is quite well done; there is quite a bit of citrus character here, is it the Sorachi Ace, the lemon zest, or the coriander, likely it is a combination of all three. The hop character is well integrated, and also contributes a soft pine note as well as some subtle menthol notes. There is an oral nasal musky, musty, Brett like note that is more noticeable as an aromatic note after taking my first sip.

The flavor has a musky, musty, smoothly phenolic, signature Brettanomyces character to it. This melds well with a dry, citrus zest character, a soft earthy spiciness, and a wheat derived spiciness as well as tartness. The beer itself also has some other tartness to it, though the totality of this is at a fairly soft level. The beer has a light bitterness, but this definitely has a bite to it, and is just a bit more characterful than is found in your typical Wit. The body of this brew is exceedingly light, yet it somehow doesnt seem thin or washed out, though it is missing the traditional wheat-derived chewiness. The finish sees the Chardonnay barrel making itself none; notes of coconut, melon, lightly spicy fruit notes, some oaky astringency, and a toasty woodiness boosts the complexity of this beer considerably, yet retains a supporting, well integrated role in the overall flavor profile. As the beer warms up it seems to pick up a fullness that is wrapped up in the oak, and to a lesser degree hop, astringency. Adding the yeast produces a roundness, and softening of the hop character, while bringing out a touch of rubbery yeast character and a champagne like nuttiness.

The oak / Chardonnay character is just fantastically well done in such a light beer; it doesnt overwhelm the beer at all and is just one side of the interplay of yeast, spice, and malt character.  The carbonation could be a bit more spritzy, but in truth it is well in line with what it should be for a Wit, for some reason I prefer a higher than normal carbonation in a well-made, complex Wit, which this beer certainly is. I really like how restrained the earthy, dirty, coriander character in this beer is; Anchorage either used a quality variety of coriander (that focused more on the citrus side of coriander), or they used a very restrained hand. In the end this is just plainly a fantastic  Wit; I am certainly a sucker for these, and this one really hits the spot. The only thing I could ask for is a bit more tartness, from a historical perspective this is quite the tartness could be here, and in fact is preferred for me; that would put this beer over the top; I do feel that this is nit-picking just a bit in a Wit of this caliber, as there are very few versions that I would rank higher than this (but this is also somewhat a departure from the style, given its Sorachi Ace character). The Sorachi Ace hopping though compliments the citrusy / lemon character that is traditionally found in a Wit, but there is an added herbal and bitter dimension that just works so well in this beer.

Light to medium sweet flavor with pissy hops and poopy brett, citrus fruits, mild hay bitterness. Light to medium bodied with average carbonation and smooth texture. Clean and funky on the finish with a bit of dank brett impression, some further citrus character. Great stuff. (August 2014, Score: 4.0)

Bottle at Eulogy. Pours a light yellow gold with a big fizzy head. Looks nice. Light toasted wheat backbone but the Chardonnay barrel flavors are up front. Big oaky lemon notes. Slightly funky sour. Green banana. White peppercorns. Straw. Green tea. Medium body. The light flavors that are present are full and well blended, though not very deep.

The beer pours a slightly hazy, pale straw-yellow body topped with a tall but fragile frothy white head that collapses upon itself leaving moderate lacing down the sides. Has a glowing, ghostly look to it. Aroma of hay, sweet wheat, lemon zest, spruce, oak, cedar, funk, and light tartness. Love it. Background has a distinct brett smell: mix of some funky barnyard smells with a hint of green apple sourness and oak as well.
Lightly tart and quenching, finishes dry. Lemon pith, herbaceous notes from the hop varietal, smooth with a light spiciness that lingers, but subdued in the background.  Reminds me more of a Saison than a Witbier. Citrus and wheat, tangy and quite drinkable. The Sorachi Ace hops really add nicely to the lemon profile.  It finishes with a beautifully smooth vanilla oakiness. Light bodied, with a slightly sour nature  that puckers the tongue. Overall though, this is a delicate feeling ale with mild carbonation. Overall, this is the most original take on the Witbier that Ive tasted. I love Saisons so this ones right in my sweet spot. Im really impressed with this first Ohio offering from the Anchorage Brewing Company.
Wow.  Brett comes through on the nose, a bit abrasively but is nice.  Mouthfeel is light at first, almost disappointing, but then, boom, creamy oak aftertaste with a hint of peach.  This is stunning.

750ml bottle, shared during a family dinner. Minimal white head. Mildly hazy yellow color. Pretty continously ascending little bubbles in the body. Bits of slowly falling lace. This is the most interesting take on a Belgian Wit Ive ever heard of - with Brett, and aged on oak barrels? Also probably the most expensive Ive had, too. Nice light fine soft carbonation, dry finish. Its a really nice complex aroma. Orange-peel, peppercorns are noticable in the aroma, but its nice and subtle - the brett is more subtle than I expected too, appropriate for a witbier. Its a really nice tart taste, light sour. Doesnt taste woody, but theres a note of chardonnay. All of these gimmicks work pretty nicely together. Very nice zesty taste. Hazy on the last pour, with a nice white head, that fades a bit. The price is a bit too much for me to do more than once. For that reason, I wanted to dislike this going in, but Ive got to admit, it impressed me. Very nice to sip, and very interesting.

In short: A complex and refreshing funky session wheat beer that defies categorization.  Fantastic
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed six months after purchase.  Bottle forwarded to me by oakbluff, thanks a lot Scott
The look: Partly cloudy yellow-straw color body topped by a small white head
In long: Nose is truly farmhouse. It has a clear bright bretty character that is not too intense and has funny notes of parmesan cheese, lemony meringue, wet white wine barrel, more  Taste is insanely refreshing but the beer does not compromise on complexity.  Fresh slice of low-sweetness homem lemon pie with a nice meringue, plenty of fresh crisp wheat, kiwis and other exotic fruits, coriander, freshly squeezed lemon juice, nice white cheese, light notes of white wine, funk, astringent wood barrels.  And I could go on an on Body is juicy and with a lot of small tickling bubbles.  One word that best describe all the flavors of this beer (an there are many) is bright.  I LOVE each and every Anchorage beers but Im really surprised that the Whiteout is currently my favourite.  By style alone I would have suspected the Saison or maybe the Galaxy or the Tripel.  But no, their wheat beer is my favourite.  But with such alive beers, a lot of it depends on when you drink them.  This Whiteout is truly a desert island beer, certainly not the most intense beer out there, but so complex and so drinkable that I could imagine drinking only this beer for the rest of my life.  Fantastic beer that I need to keep in stock at home

750 ml bottle from Wine and Cheese Place. Pours a pale, hazy straw color with a finger of bone white head that settles into a small, lasting cap. Bouteille de 750 ml. Arômes doux et complexes de vin blanc, de brettanomyces et dagrumes. Robe blonde et trouble, légère dentelle et effervescence assez active. Vraiment très délicate et raffinée en bouche, cette bière montre les caractéristiques attendues dune wit (blé, agrumes) ainsi quune belle touche de vin blanc et de brettanomyces. Finale délicatement acide. Très belle texture nuageuse. Vraiment une belle création, dangereusement facile à boire.

Bottle, purchased at Hill Farmstead.  Hazy yellow with a fizzy white head.  Nose is lemon, oak, lightly buttery chardonnay notes, lots of pineapple brett.  Nice, smooth flavor, some more lemon, pineapple, buttery oak.   Not quite up to par with some of the others but still damn tasty.

Aroma of Brett, citrus, leather, light grass with some fruit and malty feel to it as well. Some wood and light citrus fruity notes. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and somewhat oily texture. Moderated sweet and light bitter flavor with some acidic. Wood and light acidic finish with some fruity notes.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2012 Bottle to pint. Looks solid; a hazy yellow with lots of head. Smells funky; like baby shit. Tastes nothing like it smells (which is a good thing). Chardonnay. Nice on the palate. I dont know if I can revisit this due to how offensive it smells.

text: Wow this is one hell of a wit. Pours hazy straw color with a decent white head that slowly fades. Smells nice and funky with your other ordinary wit characters of coriander. Taste is good and clean with coriander notes and hints of funk and oak, I was hoping for it to have a little sourness to it but oh well its still fantastic.

Sample at Ale Wine & Spirits in Powell on 06/07/2012. This beer is a slightly cloudy straw color with a medium foamy white head that evaporates steadily to an outer ring. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus, oak and dank basement. Light to medium body with a slightly funky character and notes of wood, malt and citrus. The finish is semi-tart and medicinal with a ripe fruit aftertaste. I was excited to try this but ultimately doesnt quite come together.

750mL bottle, no date for $14.99 from Olive Tree Market a few months back.  Fairly clear pale straw with a 1 1/2 finger fizzy white head that didnt stay around long.  Definitely getting the buttery brett element up front with plenty of wheat backing.  Ive got some oak as well, but the brett seems to be masking what little coriander I do get.  Lightly acidic lemon pulp and zest round out the aroma.  The acidic pulp actually gets a fair amount stronger as it warms.  The flavor does have a more lemony component, but with just a tinge of the acidity (not much compared to the warmed up aroma). Still has lots of brett, getting a bit barnyardy, but even more butteryness. Pretty low on the sweetness.  Semi-dry finish, scant bitterness.  Moderate prickly carbonation with a light body. Not too bad, but this is the one I liked the least from Anchorage, and would not buy again at 2/3 the price. I like this a bit less than the numbers show.

The aroma is spices, a hint of citrus and tartness from the barrels.  The flavor is spices, fruit/berries, lemons and a tart finish.  Interesting style to barrel age, gave it an almost lambic and lemonade flavor, pretty good.

Sigh. Light yellow pour with a white head. The head leaves right away but the carbonation sticks around, very prickly. Aroma is butter, oak, and some funk. Flavor is a butterbomb, just too much for me. Everything else youd think would be in this is around, but I cant get over the butter. Thin finish, just not my thing.
