Medium body, moderate carbonation and foamy mouth-feel. Good balance and easy drinking. A very good Witbier.

A - Pours a clear golden-yellow with a finger of frothy white head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of lemon zest and sweet wheat with some funkiness, barnyard smells, and some brett. Hint of green apple sourness and oak as well.

T - Starts off some barnyard funkiness, brett, some green apple sourness, a bit of wheat, and some tart lemon zest. Through the middle, some light oak flavors come through with a hint of spices alongside some mellowing tartness. The finish is a mix of wheat, tart lemon zest, funky brett, and a hint of oak.

M - Medium-light bodied with moderate carbonation. Smooth with a tart, dry, and crisp finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nice complex witbier beer with the Brett flavor really blended in nicely. Super crisp and refreshing as well.

Refrigerated 75 cl corked and caged bottle, batch #1, dated May 2011 from joepeesie poured into a weizen glass.  Pours translucent pale golden with msall white head taht dissapates quickly.  Good big bubble lacing, medium body, and funk/citrus aroma.  Taste starts sweet citrus (mostly lemon), coriander, funky sour yeast, some oak, some vineous, and hint of pepper.  Complex version of a white beer, a little better as it warms.  Another good selection Joe.

Bottle 750ml.Clear light to medium yellow colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, grain, citrus, lemon, moderate yeasty, coriander, oak, barnyard notes. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and light moderate bitter with a average to long duration, lemon, citrus, oak - white wine, brett. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120128]

750mL bottle, pours a cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma of citrus peel, coriander, white wine and oak. Flavour of white wine, slight sourness from the wine, oak barrels, coriander, citrus peel and a lemon tang. Quite flavourful for the style, though not terribly exciting.

Great super hazy golden blonde coloured body with a dense, thick white head. Aroma of yeast, gueuze, sour grapes, cherries, oak and a pleasant amount of coriander seed and curacao. Light-bodied; Slightly sour flavour at first reminds of a gueuze, then shows a lot of light wheat and yeast flavours, some light spices and a touch of the dry tastes. Aftertaste is nice and complex with the majority of flavours in the wheat and yeast ranges with a touch of alcohol noticeable and some light spices as well. Overall, a very nice wit, with tons of good flavours and a subtle complexity that finishes this off very nicely. I sampled this 75 cL bottle purchased from La Bodega in Anchorage, Alaska on 23-June-2011, sampled at home in Washington on 29-April-2012, even though Ive seen it for sale on this side of the USA, a very nice beer to bring back across the whole of America.

Bottle with friends. Pours a hazy straw yellow with plenty of head. Aroma is amazing. Tart funkiness, lots of horsey brett, with some definite fruitiness. Taste is bone dry, very tart, and really nice and funky. you can almost taste the chardonnay coming through. Its impossible to compare this to other wits since its so different. Really fantastic.

Bottle split with James, Tony, Pat, Tom, and Dallas, compliments of Dallas. Pours a murky piss color with large white head, lots of tiny bubbles. Aromas of ultra tart funk, barn, coriander, oranges, lemon leather. Taste was a fresh watery gueze with fruits and wood. Refreshing and not overtop sour. Awesome combination

750 ml bottle.  Pours a clear pale gold with a large fizzy white head and lots of carbonation bubbles streaming to the surface.  Very pleasant aroma of brett funk that does not overwhelm the beer.  There is some oak in the nose as well.  The flavor is brett funk, but again, the funkiness does not overwhelm the rest of the beer and is well proportioned in the flavor profile.  Oak, grape, and a touch of wheat present as well.  Excellent!

Bottle shared by Kevin.  Clear yellow pour, lasting carbonation and a nice slightly sweet aroma.  Flavor is effervescent white grapes, pears and a little dry and oaky on the aftertaste.  Very nice, would definitely buy this.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. This beer is crazy. Typical wheat beer pour with a nice, long lasting white head on top. Lacing clings to the sides of the glass. The nose is very odd. It smells sweet and sour. The brett is very noticable and I seem to get a buttery note coming off it. Heaps of lemon and orange zest come out with a nice balance of spices as well. Taste is all spice at first. Strong finish of brett. As it warms, more zest comes out and it becomes a little buttery. Odd. Almost a chardonnay with all that butter and citrus. Crazy beer

Another solid brew from this company. 

What stood out for me was  the white grape, oak and wheat blend. Odd, but interesting. I love that this company uses oak barrels. Barrel aged is the best.

Larôme habituelle de funk Anchorage accompagné de zest de citron et dun peu de gingembre. En bouche, la vanille explose de façon inattendu avec des notes de vin blanc boisé bien enrobante. À chaque essai, mes genoux plis un peu plus devant cette brasserie aux talents multiples.

Bottle: Batch #1, bottled May 2011, enjoyed late March 2012.  Pours a clear greenish yellow with a white head that stays around for a while, then fades completely.  Aroma is brett and lacto sourness, buttery oak, coriander, green apple, sour pear.  Taste is all of the above bathed in buttery oak overtones.  Body is medium, silky, frothy, long dry buttery finish.  Overall, refreshing and delightful.

Flaske: Lysegul øl diset med et lille skumhoved. Havde lignet en klassisk wit hvis der havde været et skumhoved. Duften er meget frugtet fra brett, men er samtidig en tand off. Lover ikke godt for smagen. Men der tager jeg heldigvis helt fejl. Super lækker kompleks smag, hvor både sorachi humlen, bretten og fadlagringen på chardonnay kommer til sin ret. Der er simpelthen smag fra det hele uden at det clasher. Eneste problem er at det bliver en tand saftevandsagtig, men på den gode måde. Er sgu helt pjattet med Anchorage og deres over the top syn på at lave øl.

Very good.   Clear gold with a bright white head.  Light floral hops aroma.  The flavor is crisp and dry with plenty of brett and funk.  Not much wheat for a wit but I dont mind.  A nice session beer if you can afford it
From a bottle poured a straw color with a small amount of head.  Light tart malty flavor with a quick finish.

Pours a clear gold with a nice white head and fizzy carbonation throughout the glass.  Smell yields barnyard funk initially that quickly gives way to dry citrus, some light floral notes, subtle oak/woodsy notes, some residual sugary elements.  Tastes of coriander, dry wheat, mild citrus, some oaky vanilla, some peppery splashes.  Sophisticated with a reserved breaddy finish.

Pale golden with a disappearing white head. Aroma of brett funk and white wine, with notable orange peel and a touch of banana. Sweet fruity flavour with a refreshing tartness kicking in. Coriander is noticed in the finish

Nose is nice and funky, definite oak chardonay barrel notes, light wit, some lemon, barnyard. Interesting aromas on this one for sure. Very unique. Pours hazy golden yellow, nice fizzy white head and solid sheets of lace. Wit base beer notes, some chardonay citrus fruits, funky brett barnyard, some coconut here and there. Interesting take on a wit. Well carbonated. Light and fruity. Solid.

Bright lightly hazed straw yellow with a quickly dissipating white head.  Punky oak, funky barnyard doo-doo, lemon, vinous white grapes, light clove and belgian ester undertones.  Light refreshing body with effervescent carbonation.  Funky tart lemon, white grape, dry throughout, bit of oak, mellow whit spiciness yeast.  Light, funky, refreshing...great barrel aged variation of a whit.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave and Ben on March 17th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a..um..like lemonade!
Aroma: Aroma is light, wheaty.
Taste: Really interesting for witbear, some oak, lots of wheat, brett makin things interesting.
Palate: Nice light body..
Summary: As usual, or shall I say the once a year Ben finds an Anchorage brew and is kind enough to share it with me, this was really tasty.

Really really good and really unique.  Nose is super bright...lemon, citrus, some wheat and yeast.  Palate continues that lemon and citrus but then you get the bottle conditioned yeast, some grass and a lot of light dancing carbonation and the dry oakiness of the barrel aging.  Super drinkable yet super full of flavor.  The finish is very dry and oaky.  Really interesting great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2012 Location: 750 ml bottle from Buy Rite, 3/17/12


Aroma: It has a pretty interesting nose of wheat, brett, lemon, citrus, and wood

Appearance: The pour is a cloudy, unclear golden-white, and a bright white head and good lacing

Flavor: Tastes mid sweet, a fairly heavy brett component, a good amount of citrus, and a little wood

Palate: The body is fairly light, slightly smooth, a bit of a tingly feel, and a fairly heavy bretty feel

Overall Impression: 
This was another great one from Anchorage.  Ive really enjoyed everything Ive tried from them.  This was another good one.  It had a nice feel, and the brett worked really well with the rest of the beers components.

I love Anchorage bottles. You can tell they put a lot into each design an this comes through in the beer as well. Pours pale clear yellow with a quickly dissipating white foamy head. The aroma has some pretty strong brett notes that fades over time along with a bit of spice and vinious oak. Really nice and complex. The flavor is quite tart and lemony with a nice bit of pepper in the background. Nice oaky finish that is a bit short. This is really dry and refreshing. I love this beer.

750 ml corked & caged; pale gold and crystal clear with trace white head fading quickly; pears, lemons, light cheesy brett; light pepper and a dry, sweet white wine note in the finish; really dig the level of attenuation here as compared to the Love Buzz; this drinks much smoother and refined with the spices, pepper and barrel treatment blending together harmoniously; light oranges, white pepper and again with that stale cheese brett flavor mixed with dry oak; the finish and super light mouthfeel really make his one shine

Bottle with Carla. Pours a clear yellow with a nice layer of white foam. Smells dry and sour with hints of melon and chardonnay grapes. Tastes VERY dry when cold, but as it warms up it gains some grapefruit, honeydew and toasted oak flavors. I still wish it were sweeter.

Bottle from Best Damn Beer Shop: Poured a glowing white/yellow hue that hazy and was topped by a thick lather of foamy head that eventually fizzes out.   My nose detects a sour and spicy strain of Belgian yeast that reminds me of Flemish sour ale, but there is also a scent of coriander and a strong aroma of wine too. The flavor is tart with a heaping dosage of spicy Belgian yeast and Chardonnay wine. There are plenty of spices such as coriander, pepper, lime leaf, grains of paradise and etc. however, I dont taste the most typical Belgian white beer flavor which is orange peel. Certainly, much stronger in spices than was expected and the French Oak Chardonnay over compensates by creating a monster witbier, but I wasnt taken back by this recipe.

Bottle at Kriss place, part of the epic Winnipeg tasting. Pours cloudy lemon-yellow. Thin white head, nice lacing. Nose is dirty wheat, stinky feet, creamed pineapple. Flavours of cand, wheat, canned pineapple, loads of white pepper here. What I typed above sounds like a terrible combination of flavours, but its good. Very good.

75 cl bottle @ home, batch #1, bottled 05/2011
Aroma is rather rich with earthy and oaky notes. Also some raw apples. Flavour is sour and somewhat tart with some raw apples and earthy notes. Feels like white wine. Adding the yeast makes this much more round, but gives nothing more.

75 cl bottle. Bottled/brewed? on 05/2011.
Pours hazy pale golden color with medium head. Aroma of brettanomyces, citrus, apricot, barnyard notes and spices. Flavor of citrus, apricot, vanilla, wood, yeast, spices and some rose hip. A bit too watery palate, otherwise quite nice wit. Cant quite find the chardonnay barrel here, maybe the palate has smoothened a bit by it.
3445

750 ml bottle. Batch #1, May 2011.
Pours a pale yellow colour with a white head. Aroma of strong lemon and grapefruit, grass, brett and some floral notes as well. Flavour of wheat, lemon, grapefruit, brett and sweet grapes. Dry oak smoothens the taste nicely which adds some interesting white wine -like notes here. Medium bodied, quite rich mouthfeel with a fruity, wheaty and oaky finish. Chardonnay barrel seems to work very well with a Witbier. Very tasty.

750ml bottleBatch 1, bottled 5/2011
Pours pale, clear and light yellow with a medium bubbly head. Aroma of strong brettanomyces notes, spices, yeast and earthy notes. Taste has slightly tart fruits, wheat malts, lemon, spices and some earthy notes. Finish is a bit watery with some tart fruity notes and slight hints of white wine, vanilla and wood. Nice and tasty, well balanced, not too sour.

Bottle. Hay coloured, slightly hazy. Aroma of oak, spices, citrus, brett.
Light bodied, fizzy carbonation, astringent finsish. Taste of citrusy brett, oaked chardonnay, minerals. Great beer, but a witbier? Not really

Poured into a Heady Topper pint glass.  Hazy light yellow body with almost three fingers of foamy white head.  Leaves large waves of lacing behind.  Looks great.  Lots of brett on the nose, followed by earthy wheat and a touch of citrus.  Some oak and lightly soured white grapes linger in the background.  Flavor is dry, crisp, citrus wheat.  Touch of oak and vanilla.  Light grape notes.  This stuff is delicious.  Body is crisp and refreshing.  Perfect for a Belgian-style wit.  Overall, this is awesome.  Goes down so easy.  Love the brett and wine barrels on this.  One of the best wheat beers Ive ever had.  Definitely worth seeking out.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Muddy pale yellow with a slight green hue. Smallish, staying, frothy, white head. Aroma is sweet, some mild sulphur, grapes, white wine, oak, wheat. Light citric. Medium carbonation, dry and light creamy mouthfeel with some grainy notes. Flavour is wheaty, quite sweet, sharpish grapefruit and citrus. Dry oakiness and a slight citrus twang to the nicely dry finish. A very interesting interpretation on the wit. Sadly the mid-finish lacks a bit of punch and mouthfeel to be absolutely amazing.

750ml bottle. Hazy bright yellow with small macropore white head. Wonderful spicy, yeasty and sour aroma. Complex taste has an underlying sweet wheat malt note, sour citrus, spicy coriander and pepper, some yeast in the end. Very good.

Bomber. Very very pale gold / yellow with a generous effervescent white head that just looks beautiful. Light citrus and spice, yeast, chardonnay; semi dry and somewhat sweet, moderate body and above average carbonation, smooth, becomes dryer on the finish with more wine notes, some nice spice and finally a bit of wheat. A very good beer - have not had a miss yet from Anchorage.

Pour is a cloudy yellow gold with lots of apparent carbonation. Small white that fades away slowly. Aroma is heavy lemon with some notes of funk, vinegar, and soaked bread. Flavor is much smoother than the aroma with a slightly sweet backbone. Slight vanilla, slight orange peel, bready grains, and light brett. Medium bodied, dry finish.
750 bottle-shared by EZAnt-pours hazy straw/yellow with a retaining thin white head.  Aroma is yeast, lemon, grain/wheat.  Taste is yeast, lemon, grain/wheat with some sweet.  Ok effervescence.

Bottle, 02/05/2012.  Pours clear white gold, like white wine, one finger frothy head fades, but leaves some decent lacing around the edge of my glass.  Nose carries brett, faint tart lemon, and oak, some subtle chardonnay sweetness floating on top.  In the taste is wheat malts, brett funk, hint of tart citrus, dry chardonnay finish.  Thin and dry, but carbonation adds depth.  Everything balanced, restrained.  Great light beer with lots of complexity, the funkiness almost has a lambic-like quality, reminds me of Zwanze 2011 in some ways.

Bottle. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity yeasty wheat malty bretty citrus aroma. Fruity wheat malty bretty citrus flavor. Has a dry wheat malty bretty citrus finish.

Im not sure if I believed in the hype of this beer too much, but wasnt as good as I hoped it would be. A little funk in the aroma that showed up big time in the flavor, and not like a Brett funk that I really enjoyed at a mderate level, but this was off putting funk that really took away from the overall quality of the beer. Brewers seem to be leaning away from the orange zest of a white ales yeasty flavor to more of a funky, almost lemon zest character. some people might like that, but not my favorite evolution.

750mL bottle, Batch 1.  Poured lightly-cloudy, pale golden with a sticky white head and plenty of rising carbonation.  The aroma was quite vibrant, with cherry skins, oak, and earthy spices present.. basically in that order.. a little lemon zest and vinegar rounded it out.. came across with a lot of lambic-like character.. a lot going on, and it smelled like it was going to be super refreshing.  The flavor found tart, dry oak, white vinous notes, and prickly carbonation on the tip of the tongue.. champagne-like effervescence followed all the way through.. earthy notes, lemon meat, and wheat at the core.. lots of vinous notes and fruity Brett on the back-end.. finished dry and refreshing.  Light-medium bodied with high carbonation on the palate.. great balance between the wit, the barrel, the Brett, and the spices.. this was well thought out, and almost perfectly executed!
Bottle. Hazy yellow with small white head. Aroma is brett, oak, wheat and white wine. Flavour is malt, wheat, brett, little citrus, fruit, oak and dry.
Hazy yellow of color with a small white head. An aroma of citrus, white wine, green grapes, spice and soap. A flavor of citrus, dry, spice and oak.
Bottle @ Too many Geuzes - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head. White wine, oak, perfume , breyy, and spices. Crisp and dry. Lovely.
Hazy pale yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, wheaty, citrus, light bretty and white wine. Flavor is medium sweet. Dry finish. 280112
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with medium duration. Color is pale yellow. Aroma and taste are yeast, wheat malt, citrus, coriander and notes of wood.
Sampled at the Day After Thanksgiving Tasting.  Murky straw pour.  Big bretty but clean funk is the predominant note. Not much of the wit flavor, but overall, this was pretty damn tasty.
Pours yellow with an off white head. Aroma is a touch of oak and lemon. Has a spiced flavor and a warm haze.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is spiced, citric and brett. Coriander and brett mixed - strange citric to this. Dry fruity, brett and crisp hoppy. Dry and fruity finish.

Bottle for Patriots playoff game.  Pours very light yellow with white head. Great nose of Brett and funk.  Tastes of Brett, oak, citrus, chardonnay, slight sourness, and oak.  Really tasty and refreshing I love Anchorage thus far

Pale yellow golden pour white head ... aroma is of light oak, brett like a geuze with some barnyard and lemon .... taste is of brett, lemony, barnyard, dry sour grapes, peppercorn and spicy coriander with light oak ... very dry peppery finish ..... another winner from these guys like a geuze/wit combo

This is about as good as it gets for this style. It pours a completely translucent straw yellow with a good-sized white head and has a sour, twangy, vinegary nose. You get the brett, some lemon, a sour twang, a bit of cedar, and some hops upon tasting. This is a nice beer that I would compare to Leelanaus wit, though I dont think I like it quite as much.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of Storm. Opaque yellow with a white head. Very fresh Bretty aroma combined with a little citrus. Light body with dry citric notes combined with tropical fruits and a light edge of wood. Dry, Bretty and sulphurous with a vague underlying sweetness. Very refreshing - like a modern take on Orval! 311211
Clear peach colored pour. Nose is very floral, sweet wines, barrel, funk and tartness. Flavor is spices, orange, flowers, and nice Brett funk. Palate is light and crisp. this one was nice.

(750ml bottle from Total Wine Reno).  Pours a cloudy straw color with a white head.  Active carbonation.  Aroma has some earthiness, grapes, wheat,  spice.  Taste is sweet malts and earthiness with a bit a tartness.  Light bodied and fizzy.  Pretty good and quite unique.

24th October 2011Bottle in hotel room before flying out to Genoa. Hazy pale gold beer. Tidy, but short lived bubbly white head. Light palate, crispy and semi dry. Light seltzer minerals. Light brett and wine flavours. Semi dry finish. Not getting any spice except a trace of white pepper. A light and easy going beer, unusual and very drinkable.

This literally poured a straight white color, just barely light yellow with a white head. Aroma was lots and lots of brett, some funky, and rotten egg too.  Flavor was good bit of funk and brett, lots of cheese taste, though not really tart at all.  Not much of the wit beer remains underneath but still an interesting brew.

pours a clear and light yellow color. Poured from 750 into a hefewizen glass with a small head that goes away fast

great aromas of funk, lemons, varied citrus, and some bits of grassy/wheaty tones. It certainly shows the brett influence on the nose and while its a bit conflicted due to the style, its one that I enjoy

lighter bodied with a very nice feel. Lacking some depth, but very fresh with flavors of lemon zest, fresh citrus fruits

an extremely good wit. The brett on this does make it different. Since I generally love sour characteristics, its fine by me, but this may not work for a lot of people. That said, this is and has been enjoyable with a real refreshing style

Had this at the 2011 Pittsburgh Ratebeer Christmas Eve Eve Tasting.  Big thanks to Lithy for this rocking beer. Very nice fresh beery white beer aroma with a hint of citrus. Poured from a bomber.  The presentation in the glass is very attractive; looks very bubbly and fun. First taste impression is that this is a good friendly beer, some tartness in there. Just enough bitterness to let you know this is beer but it never tries to go over the top. Simply a really good beer tasting experience. THANKS JUSTIN!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Rating #100 for this beer. Bottle  from a trade with dmac. Pours cloudy straw color with white head. Aromas of wheat, corriander, vanilla, oak and brett. Tastes like a wibier up front and finished with oak, vanilla, brett and a hint od wine. Medium body with average carbonation and a dry finish. A strange beer, but the more I drank, the more I enjoyed it. Thanks Dave.

Bottled. A yellow beer with no head. The aroma has notes of brettanomyces, lemons, straw, and wheat. The flavor is sweet and acidic with notes of lemons, brettanomyces, straw, and wheat, leadingto a dry bretty finish.

transparent gold with thin white head, Chardonnay heavy nose, Brett heavy, eggy. Flavor is more chardonnay, light pineapple and wood mid palate, crisp citrus with light pepper and wheat grains in finish. Thin body, sticky with light carbonation, astringent and singular, masking base badly.

Clear whitish yellow, white puffy color.  Aroma is all oaky, some bretty.  Taste is a bit odd, some lavender, oak, white wine, but a bit musty or cheesy.  I dunno, I dont get much witbier character here.
bottle, shared with Rudolf. Paler straw color, hazy. bretty funk is present but a little subdued. Coconut notes, lemon citrus, light soapy 7 spice notes. Overall, pretty good wit & a bit unusual

Bottle (Batch #1) at Ølbutikken. Clear golden - small white head. 
Wheaty. Bretty. Citrus. Light hoppy  fruity. Peppery. Light bitterness. Light elderflowers. Nice bretty fresh finish.

Bottle at Ølbutikken.
Hazy yellow coloured with a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of brett, vanilla, citrus and spices.
Fruity flavour of spices with notes of citrus peel and hops.
Citric and hoppy finish.

Bottle shared with Mike, Steve, Ryan & Big Daddy.  Hazy light gold/yellow.  Thin white head.  Nose is cherry pit & lemon zest, very light malt.  Flavor is lemon & pit, some very light spice.  a bit watery.  Nice strong bitterness in the finish.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2016 cloudy  yellow, almost no head. Bretty and wheaty aroma, delicate. 8. Flavor is bretty, wheaty, dry fruit peel. 7 very nice bretty and belgian yeasty bretty wit.[8.3.7.3.16]
re-rate 2016-4-15. bottle from kihoskh. Almost clear pale yellow, fluffy white head. 3. Very nice refreshing citrussy and bretty and wheaty belgian wit kinda aroma. 8.   Flavor is a bit sweeter than aroma, and i think the sweetness is due to the barrelling, some sweet fruity notes as well as some boozy notes. It tastes a lot stronger alc% wise than it is, and i think i would have preferred an before barrel version. The added sweet woody flavors are too much for the delicate brew. 7palate 3   ov 14.   ive had way better tasting beers from achorage.

Bottle, courtesy GT2, thank you! Pour is hazy white/gold with a nice white head, good retention/lace. Aroma of chardonnay, oak, fruity esters, citrus, lemon, dust. Taste is quite dry, lightly bitter, tropical notes (pineapple, pear), vanilla, oak. Palate is soft, crisp, very dry. Drank this with BA stateside, both were excellent and very comparable.

Lemonaide colored beer with a big white fizzy head.  Light funky nose with some citrus peel and wet blanket.  There is an old grapefruit rind tartness with some spice, bitter orange juice and funk.  The flavors seem a bit harsh.  I blame the wine barrels.  It is a bold Belgian wit, Ill give it that.
Bottle.  Cloudy light yellow pour.  Aroma of fresh coconut, vanilla, and oak.  Funky barnyard flavor mixed with lemon and some fruit pit.  Medium sourness.

bottle. Pours hazy blonde white head, nose lactic, brett, woody lemony citrus,
nice earthy cherry pit undertones, long bright spritzy character, good
stuff very drinkable

Bottle @ The BeerMongers... Poured hazy, vibrant, pale yellow with a thick, frothy white head.  Nice retention and lacing.  Big wood flavors with notes of citrus, grapefruit, kiwi, champagne yeast spice and a noticeable brett-like funk and footy characters.  Earthy wheat flavors, mildly sweet malt, horse blanket, vanilla malted wheat, with a drying finish.  Body was not too thin with a decent mouthfeel and carbonation.

Batch 1 750. Beautiful clear golden pour with gigantic visible carbonation and a beautiful frothy head. Nose holds absolutely superb brett notes with lemon, hay, farmhouse funk, and tannic oak. The flavor is slightly more muted but still superb, with extremely pleasant woody sour brett presence. Not particularly dry at the start, but all of a sudden it explodes with a puckering tart dryness right at the finish. This brewery is putting out damn fine beer.

Thanks craftycarl21! Clear yellow pour with a massive frothy white head. The nose is absolutely incredible. The brett character is some of the best Ive ever encountered. Massive cheesecloth, pineapple, tropical fruits, white grape juice, and farmy funk. Cheesecake, juicy nectar fruits, eathen brett, and tropical fruits abound in the flavor. The palate is light, but extremely quaffable. Ample caressing and silken carbonation with a super dry yet somehow juicy finish.

(750ml bottles, batch 1) Pours a hazy pale yellow body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of lemon peel, wheat, coriander, chardonnay, brett, and oak.  Flavor of yeast, earth, wheat, lemon, florals, vanilla, and brett.

Pours very light gold with a medium head.  A lot of sour citrus in the aroma, along with spice and some grassiness.  Taste is not what I expected, but in a good way.  Starts out light with some wood and finishes with wood, grass, and some sour flavor, but less than youd expect from the aroma.  Finish is light and very dry.  Very drinkable, especially given the alcohol content.

Bottle; Pour is slightly murky light golden with a pillowy white head in this glass - light lacing is present here. The nose is quite musky - with lemon rinds, white pepper, and earth. The flavor profile provides a sweeter undertone - with more musky basement and hay (brett), lemons, white pepper, with some of the oaked elements peeking through near the finish - ending on the dry side - another nice, overpriced anchorage brew, by my estimation

750ml, caged and corked bottle. Poured a straw color with an averaged sized head. Aromas of mustiness, funky, spices, and oak. Tastes of bread, lighter funk, spices, citrus, and Chardonnay. Dry finish. Interesting.
bottle, thanks to gt2 in trade, bright yellow with creamy foam, has a good sour funky and bitter lemon aroma, flavor is bitter lemon with some sour milk and funk

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 Bottle thanks to Blutt59. Pours a cloudy bright yellow with fizzy head. Notes of farmhouse, citrus, musty, lemon hints and earthy, dry. Medium body with high fizzy carbonation. Overall, solid.

Another tasty brewed provided by Dallas. This corked and caged 75cl bottle pours totally opaque pale gold with white head. The aroma is both tart and funky with a bit of acidity and a bit of earthy moldy citrus. The taste has a good deal of bitter tartness with citrus acidity and some old expired citrus like funkiness. Around these notes theres also mild wheat notes off in the background. Good stuff.

bottle-pours lightly hazy dark yellow with a spritzy white head around the rim of the glass with cascading carbonation,  this nose is off the chain-lots of wood, funk, spice (corriander), white grapes, estery funk from the brett and some phenols from the lemon. The aroma was moderate lemony citrus, doughy malts, mild chardonnay notes and a touch of oak.  The flavor is more lemony citrus with some mild chardonnay influences. Tasted on 11/13/11 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle purchased at City Beer, thanks to Ben for sharing.  Pours cloudy, bright yellow with a thick white head that leaves a thin layer of even lace.  The nose is very dry and funky with very light malt, classic witbier orange peel and spices, and a malolactic Chardonnay character.  The flavor is similar, extremely dry with spices, orange peel, and the same fruity and lactic Chardonnay character from the nose.  The body is light with lively carbonation and a long, very dry, funky, and oaky Chardonnay finish.

Pours a slightly hazy, pale golden yellow color with visible carbonation bubbling up and a two finger frothy, pillowy white head that slowly settles into a thick cap/ring. Large streaks and chunks of soapy lacing are left behind. 

Earthy aroma with lots of zesty spice along with some musty, bretty funk and vinous light fruit. Lots of peppery spice, lemon zest and coriander followed by bready yeast, musty brett and light fruits. The barrel presence is there but the Chardonnay is more prominent in the nose than the oak giving off hints of grape, cider and pear. 

Medium bodied with soft carbonation and crisp effervescence up front that linger over the slightly funky, sweet vinous body into a slight dry finish. Theres a good amount of zesty spice, bready yeast and light fruit but the flavor is dominated by the Chardonnay barrel character. The spice profile has hints of pepper and coriander as well as a boatload of citrusy lemon zest that is complimented by the dry brett. The Brett provides some nice dryness and faint funk but doesnt overpower the other notes. The barrel presence kicks in mid-palate and really dominates the flavor through the finish. Theres only subtle toasted oak adding to the dryness but the Chardonnay character is very prominent giving off sweet vinous notes that balances things out. Lots of sweet fruit notes, especially light grapes, apple cider and pear. I would even say that its a bit too strong taking away slightly from the other elements. Still, this beer is flavorful, very complex and easy to drink. 

Overall this beer could use some balance to counter the Chardonnay sweetness but is still pretty impressive. Another solid offering from this up and coming brewery.

text: 750 ml bottle shared by EZAnt. Poured a grenish/yellow with a small tight foamy bright white head. Aroma of tropical fruit, apricot, nectarine, brett, chardonnay, oak. Medium body with strong carbonation and a dry lingering finish. Flavor of cream, brett, tropical fruits, and orange cream sickle. Solid and enjoyable.

750ml bottle.  Batch #1 from May 2011, aged about 4 months in the bottle.  A careful pour reveals a hazy, pale golden-straw body strewn with effervescing streams of pin-point bubbles.  A moderate head of snow white foam is built on those pooling micro bubbles, slowly subsiding to a thin outer ring with a wispy film at the center.  Lacing is comprised of a dense, hard drying, patchy ring that coats nearly the entire glass.  Gorgeous looking brew.The aroma is a melange of complimentary elements.  Starting out, there is the clean wheat grain base, lightly sweet, hinting also at creamy oats with a drop of floral honey.  Brettanomyces is instantly recognizable, imparting a dusty, earthy bite that matches the subtle peppercorn and coriander spicing nicely.  Lemon pith adds a dry acidity, while Berliner Weiss-like lacto notes lend slightly eggy, sulfuric underpinnings.  Then there is the Chardonnay barrel influence, which comes in the form of creamy French Vanilla oak and soft kisses of honeysuckle or pear.  The nose is well structured, complex, and varied.  In terms of style, it is very difficult to pigeonhole....and I like thatThe flavor is very similarly structured.  Right off the bat, the dusty, slightly tart brett imparts an earthy, woody bite.  Coriander and white pepper transition closely behind, intensified by lively, fine carbonation.  At the mid point, the creamy, honey-kissed wheat pushes through, bringing with it a slightly more acidic and brite lemon note.  Barrel influence seems more woody and less fruit driven, as I dont quite pick up the orchard fruit that the aroma suggests.  Likewise, the lactobacillus tendencies present in the nose are a bit more subdued, yet still present on the finish, especially a few seconds after the swallow.  Overall, it remains complex, challenging, and tasty.In the mouth, the beer does not disappoint.  There is ample substance from the wheaty malt base, with just enough sugar to give it a respectable body.  It exceeds the weight of your average witbier, yet remains well shy of some of the awful "imperial wits" that were so popular in 2009.  Carbonation is persistent and cleansing, accentuating the spice elements up front and then wiping the palate clean of the residual sugars on the back end.  Each sip begs the next.Overall, I was quite impressed with Gabes first solo commercial offering.  It defies classification, evoking the spirit of Orval, Calabaza Blanca, and Temptation equally, while simultaneously defining itself as something completely unique.  Im excited to see what is to come as he tries out some styles that I am more drawn to.

Sweeter oak profile persists and is apparent... Flavors are mich of the same with a semi-sweet citrus wit profile while some late addition of white wine qualities surface. Somewhat doughy nature and a hint of earthy tart dryness on the backend. Softer bodied and quite drinkable all around.  Would like to have a few of these to see the Brett character take hold.
Bottle.    Aroma of nice floral white wine grape rustic grassy wheat.   Taste is bright, zest grassy lemons,  wheat,    earthy toasty bitter wheat grass.   Sessionable.  Tasty.  Liked quite a bit.

750ml bottle thanks to largadeer.  Slightly hazy golden-yellow color with a small white head.  The aroma is a little strangely funky with some sunscreen, oak, pineapple, and brettiness.  Maybe a bit vegetal.  The flavor is better, although theres a bit of Coppertone sunscreen.  Also pineapple, coconut, chardonnay, and oak barrel.  Medium-bodied and dry with average carbonation.  Overall, not great.  Maybe with some age this could mellow out a bit, but for now its probably more useful to spread on your skin for a sunny day at the beach, as the SPF is no doubt pretty high.

Bottle from Beer Revolution. To call this a witbier is a bit misleading... and I mean that in a good way. This is really a straight up American wild ale/sour whatever you wanna call it.  The pour is very witbier like however. Very light, cloudy yellow with a large fizzy white head. The nose is very bretty with buttered bread, pepper, coriander, funky manure, vanilla, lemon, wheat.  Flavor is luxurious with lots of florals and spices, tart lemony, phenolic brett in the finish. Nice vanillin notes and tons of chardonnay. Not sour by any means, but very wild. I was left wanting a bit more sour flavors to complement the funk and spices, but thats not what this beer is. The brettanomyces lingers in the back of the throat as the manure, buttered bread and spices waft through your senses, backed up by the tropical, woody, toasty chardonnay notes. I really liked this a whole lot and am looking forward to more from Anchorage. It would be interesting to see how this would  taste in two years.

750mL bottle, purchased at Whole Foods - Coddingtown. Pours a beautiful, bright yellow color with brilliant clarity; huge, fluffy white head with great retention and lacing; awesome-looking pour on this. Delicious, lightly buttery Chardonnay notes and soft, toasty brettiness in the aroma; nicely dry, and a peppery and coriander wit character layered underneath; mouthwatering; a multi-tiered onslaught of yum. Medium bodied; high, effervescent CO2; lots of toasty and lightly buttery (in a good, non-diacetyl sort of way) Chardonnay notes first and foremost, taking me back to those earliest days of RR Temptation; lightly toasted oak, some citrus character, and a rounded, peppery witbier lurking underneath everything; a beautifully rendered beer, probably the first new beer Ive had in maybe six months that makes me damn excited about whats to come. Excellent stuff. Modest finish: slightly iodine-like note at the end, bitter yeastiness, nicely dry.

Bottle (batch 1, May 2011).  $14.99. Hazy golden body with a pretty, medium sized white head that lasts and gives great lace. Aromas of candi sugar, citrus peel, coriander, tons of white wine, chardonnay, oak, tannins, brett c, tropical fruit, esters, honey suckle, vanilla, gardenias, floral and perfumy. Flavors of straw, grainy, gardenia, vanilla, oak, floral, brett, funk, flowers. White wine. Very nice! Lively bubbles, dry, tasty, medium bodied.

At $15, Id still buy this again decently often. A truly amazing first beer; looking forward to any and all things Anchorage!
